Introduction

Oral cancer arises from the mucosal surfaces of the oral cavity, and >90% are squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs).  Long-term tobacco and alcohol use are the most significant risk factors.  Patients typically present with a nonhealing intraoral ulcer or exophytic mass.  Early detection and treatment are critical because prognosis declines markedly with advanced-stage disease.

Risk factors



Most cancers of the oral cavity, which include the anterior tongue, inner lips, hard palate, floor of the mouth, buccal mucosa, and gingiva, are squamous cell carcinomas (SCC).  Major risk factors include:



  • Tobacco use (smoking and chewing).
  • Excessive alcohol consumption.
  • Betel leaf/areca nut chewing (popular in Southeast Asia/India).
  • Chronic contributors:  Poor oral hygiene, chronic oral infections (eg, Candida albicans), and repetitive trauma (eg, ill-fitting dentures), which perpetuate inflammation and epithelial injury.


Notably, infection with high-risk human papillomavirus, which is strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancer (eg, tonsillar, tongue base tumors), has a low prevalence in oral cavity cancers.

Pathogenesis



Prolonged exposure to carcinogens (eg, tobacco, alcohol) and chronic irritation initiate cellular injury by directly damaging DNA and generating reactive oxygen species, which promote mutagenesis.  Over time, these insults lead to the accumulation of mutations and epigenetic modifications in the basal epithelial cells (ie, progenitors of squamous epithelium), disrupting the normal regulation of the cell cycle, apoptosis, and differentiation.  Key molecular events in this process include the inactivation of tumor suppressor genes (eg, p53) and the overexpression of oncogenes such as epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and cyclin D1; these changes drive unchecked cell proliferation.

Clinical presentation



Early manifestations of oral cancer include asymptomatic intraoral plaques, most notably leukoplakia and erythroplakia.



  • Leukoplakia (
    image 1
    ):  A white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be scraped off.  It represents epithelial hyperplasia and is typically asymptomatic.  Although leukoplakia is benign, it carries a variable risk of malignant transformation.
  • Erythroplakia (less common):  A fiery red, velvety patch that cannot be clinically or pathologically classified as any other disease.  It is more likely than leukoplakia to show significant dysplasia on histologic evaluation and carries a higher risk of progression to invasive carcinoma.


Disease progression and malignant transformation may result in the following signs and symptoms:



  • Nonhealing oral ulcer with indurated margins or an exophytic/infiltrative mass; the lesion may be accompanied by pain and bleeding.
  • Tooth loosening (due to lesions involving the alveolar ridge).
  • Dysarthria, dysphagia, trismus (due to space-occupying lesion in the oral cavity).
  • Paresthesia/anesthesia of lip/tongue or referred otalgia (due to cranial nerve compression).
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (from nodal metastasis).

Differential diagnosis



  • Aphthous ulcers (
    image 2
    ):  Painful, shallow ulcers that typically have an erythematous border, a gray base, and a fibrinous white membrane covering the lesion.  Most resolve spontaneously in 1-2 weeks.
  • Oral candidiasis (ie, thrush) (
    image 3
    ):  Disorder that typically presents as white, creamy plaques on the tongue or buccal mucosa, which can usually be scraped off with a tongue depressor to reveal an erythematous base.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (
    image 4
    ):  Infection that is characterized by painful, grouped vesicular eruptions on an erythematous base, often involving the lips, gingiva, and oral mucosa (ie, gingivostomatitis).  Lesions may be ulcerated and crusted, and systemic symptoms such as fever and cervical lymphadenopathy may be present.
  • Mandibular tori (
    image 5
    ):  Benign, nontender bony growths located on the lingual surface of the mandible (sublingual area).  Typically bilateral and symmetric, these slow-growing masses are covered by intact, normal mucosa and do not cause surrounding tissue destruction.
  • Oral lichen planus (
    image 6
    ):  A chronic, immune-mediated inflammatory disorder of basal keratinocytes, resulting in bilateral, symmetric mucosal lesions with a white, lacy or reticulated appearance.  Unlike SCCs, lichen planus is typically nonulcerative, nonbleeding, and nonprogressive.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia:  A white mucosal lesion with a distinct, corrugated appearance most often found on the lateral tongue.  It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus and occurs almost exclusively in patients with significant immunosuppression (eg, HIV) and frequently resolves with antiretroviral treatment; it is not premalignant.

Diagnosis



Any oral lesion persisting for >2-3 weeks warrants evaluation for malignant potential.  A thorough examination should include inspection of all mucosal surfaces within the oral cavity and palpation of the lymph nodes of the neck.  Imaging studies (eg, CT scan, MRI, positron emission tomography) are often used to assess the extent of disease (eg, local invasion, regional lymph node involvement, and distant metastases) and cancer staging, but definitive diagnosis requires biopsy and histopathologic evaluation.

Histopathology



Biopsy of a suspicious oral lesion followed by histopathologic evaluation is the gold standard for diagnosing oral SCC.  Tissue sampling should be obtained from the most clinically concerning area (eg, indurated, ulcerated, or erythroplakic regions).  Histopathologic hallmarks that support a definitive diagnosis of SCC include:



  • Cellular atypia:  Pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei, dyskeratosis (ie, premature keratinization).
  • Keratinization:  Presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges (
    image 7
    ).
  • Abnormal architecture:  Loss of squamous maturation with nests and sheets of polygonal malignant tumor cells infiltrating the submucosa (
    image 8
    ).
  • Invasion: Tumor cells breaching the basement membrane and infiltrating surrounding tissues.

Management



Treatment depends on tumor site, stage, and the patient's overall condition (eg, comorbidities, functional status).  The TNM staging system is used to classify cancers based on tumor size (T), nodal involvement (N), and distant metastasis (M).

Early-stage (stages I and II) cancers



Early-stage oral cancers (ie, localized without nodal involvement) are most often managed with surgery.  Wide local excision with histologically clear margins is the primary treatment.  Radiotherapy is an alternative for patients with small, well-demarcated lesions or those who are poor surgical candidates.

Advanced-stage (stages III and IV) cancers



Advanced-stage disease (ie, regional nodal involvement and/or extranodal metastasis) is treated with surgical resection of the primary tumor and adjuvant radiotherapy (Â± chemotherapy or immunotherapy).  Chemoradiotherapy (Â± immunotherapy) alone may be pursued when surgery is not feasible (eg, significant comorbidities, unresectable tumor).

Recurrent and metastatic disease



A combination of systemic chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and radiation is the mainstay for unresectable recurrent or distant metastatic disease.  If the disease progresses despite all interventions, palliative care or hospice can improve quality of life by optimizing symptom control (eg, palliative radiation) and providing multidisciplinary psychosocial support.

Prognosis



Five-year survival depends on several factors.  The prognosis is significantly worse in cases of advanced-stage disease, regional or distant metastases, and poorly differentiated tumors.  Oral cancer that is detected at stage I or II has a 5-year survival rate of 70%-90%, whereas survival in late-stage disease decreases to <50%.

Prevention



Primary prevention of oral cancer focuses on reducing modifiable risk factors, particularly tobacco use and excessive alcohol consumption, which act synergistically to increase cancer risk.  High-risk individuals should have regular oral examinations and timely biopsy of any suspicious lesions to facilitate early diagnosis and prevent progression to advanced-stage disease.

Summary



Oral cancer is predominantly squamous cell carcinoma and is strongly associated with long-term tobacco and alcohol use (
